definitions.definition: to give somebody information about something, especially something that was previously secret
definitions.sensetop: disclose something (to somebody)disclose that…it is disclosed that…disclose what, whether, etc…

examples.text: The spokesman refused to disclose details of the takeover to the press.
The report discloses that human error was to blame for the accident.
It was disclosed that two women were being interviewed by the police.
I cannot disclose what we discussed.
He had not fully disclosed all his business dealings.
Members of Parliament are required to disclose all their financial interests.
She refused to disclose the source of her information
She was accused of disclosing confidential material to a competitor.
He was ordered to disclose all the relevant documents.
State law requires unions to disclose financial information.
The amounts of money were higher than previously disclosed.
The company has disclosed details of new plans to expand.

definitions.definition: to allow something that was hidden to be seen

examples.text: The door swung open, disclosing a long dark passage.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Old French desclos-, stem of desclore, based on Latin claudere ‘to close’.
